Mr Terry – the entire nation did not, could not, avoid the Viet Nam war; just ask the families of the nearly 50,000 combatants who didn't come home, and those among the more than 150,000 who came back broken in body and spirit.

But the larger point is that Mitt was a shameful cheerleader FOR the war, while trying to turn the French(!) into Mormons (anyone know his success rate?) – and then later had the audacity to claim he wished he had been there.

I fear the right-wing chicken-hawks, who seem all too eager to start something with Iran.
And the one candidate to actually volunteer to serve in Viet Nam and who even RE-enlisted, John Kerry, got smeared by the GOP for his service. Classy and oh-so patriotic, the American right-wing.

To say that Romney "passed on Vietnam" is a massive understatement. Romney received five years worth of deferments from serving our country in the Vietnam War.

- In 1965, Romney received an educational deferment while studying at Stanford. While on that deferment, Romney protested against a group of his fellow students who were protesting against the Vietnam War.

- From July 1966 until February 1969, Romney received a 4-D deferment as a "minister of religion." Romney spent most of that time in France, trying to convert people to Mormonism.

- Romney then received another educational deferment, which ran through the end of 1970.

- In 2007, Romney had the nerve to tell the Boston Globe that he "longed in many respects to actually be in Vietnam and be representing our country there, and in some ways it was frustrating not to feel like I was there as part of the troops that were fighting in Vietnam.”

- As for the fact that none of Romney's sons chose to serve in the military, Romney was quoted during the 2008 campaign as explaining that "one of the ways my sons are showing support for our nation is helping to get me elected."

Many politicians from both sides of the aisle avoided the Vietnam War. But few who did so have then so actively cheerleaded for military conflict as Mitt Romney did regarding Vietnam in the 1960s and does regarding the Middle East now,

A response from the UNCTAD Secretariat.

The author mistakenly suggests that the UNCTAD World Investment Report 2012 (WIR) uses annual FDI data for India for the fiscal year ending on March 31, 2011. The Report in fact uses data for the calendar year, ending December 31, 2011. The data is not directly comparable with the fiscal year data presented by the Reserve Bank of India. The Report thus captures what happened with FDI in India through the entire calendar year and, in 2011, FDI was up.

The author rightfully points out that FDI flows to India fell in early 2012. Data for the 1st quarter of 2012 (Jan-Mar) shows that net FDI inflows to the country fell 24 per cent, compared with the same period in 2011. Nevertheless, given the ‘lumpiness’ of FDI flows it makes sense to analyze trends annually.

The results of UNCTAD's survey of TNC executives do not play any role in the statistics for FDI flows presented in the Report. The ranking of the top potential destinations for TNCs’ FDI over the period 2012-2014 has been quite stable over the history of the survey, with India frequently in the top 5 destinations.

Sherman Hemsley was one of the greatest comedic actors in the history of television. His small frame belied how big a presence he was on screen.  What energy!  He did physical comedy, bluster, laughter, braggadocio,  absurdity, pouting, stubbornness, hilarity, and, of course, rapid-fire tête-à-tête with his co-stars, better than any male comedic actor I can think of.  When I think of Mr. Hemsley, and the hilarity that ensued when he was on screen, week in and week out on The Jeffersons, I think of the great Lucille Ball.  His talent was that great.  Yet, Mr. Hemsley could also be effective in those tender moments, sometimes required when the script called for George Jefferson, to swallow his pride, check his ego, or reflect.  What an amazing talent!  I will surely miss him.

President Obama has ended the war in Iraq, taken out Bin Laden and numerous other al-Qaeda operatives, and established a timetable for getting our troops out or Afghanistan. Dictators have fallen in Libya, Egypt, and Tunisia, and our standing in the international community has improved significantly. While I certainly have strong concerns about some of our President's policies on expanding the national security state, drone strikes, and ordering the killing of American citizens, I also understand that there is no objection to a policy of President Obama that would be alleviated if Romney were President.

As for Romney, he is throwing red meat to the reactionary conservative base, but has offered little of substance regarding any of the important foreign policy challenges we face. Romney's lack of knowledge or details about such challenges should be a huge red flag for all of us, as we've seen this picture before. Under both President W. Bush and Reagan, we saw that Republican Presidents who have little interest in or knowledge about the world get easily taken in by the dangerous policies of the war-mongerers that brought us the Iraq War, or shady ideologues who brought us Iran-Contra.
